p:slide.p:title: Unicode and encodings
p:slide.p: Encodings are one of the most generally confusing things about XML
Don't worry, they're not really complicated.

ul.li: Computers store all information as numbers
Characters of text are stored as numbers
Older computers stored information in bytes
A byte is 8 bits
A bit is an off switch — binary — base 2

p:slide.p: Each bit represents a power of 2. The largest number we can store in a byte is 255.

ul.li: Older computers had a maximum of 255 characters because 1 byte = 1 character.
ASCII (merican Standard Code for Information Interchange) is the oldest standard and that only contained 128 characters (that last bit was reserved for error correction information).
Western Europeans used a 255 value character set because we have accents.
Eastern Europeans used a different 255 character set.
Greece and Russia used further different sets.

p:slide.p:title: Unicode and encodings
p:slide.p: The end result of this was that you needed to know which character set you were using before you could work out which character a number represented. This is character number 230 in a few character sets:

p:slide.p:title: Unicode and encodings
p:slide.p: The Unicode system is intended to resolve this problem.

ul.li: Started in 1987
Version 1.0 published in 1991
Currently at version 6.2
Defines a possible set of 1,114,112 possible characters
About 110,000 characters currently defined across 100 scripts
Each character has a unique number (a code point)

p:slide.p:title: Unicode encodings

ul.li: Latin 1, Latin 7, ASCII are all encodings
Encodings define the mapping from character to number
Unicode has encodings too — UTF-8, UTF-16, UCS2
XML is defined in terms of Unicode, defaulting to UTF-8

p:slide.p: UTF-8 is a mechanism for encoding characters efficiently. All the ASCII characters are stored (encoded) as a single byte. Beyond that the numbers are converted to a special format that allows them to be transmitted across a network efficiently. UTF-8 uses up to 4 bytes per character.
You don't ever see that unless something has gone wrong!
